questions.question_text: What type of attack sends SYN requests to a target system with spoofed IP addresses?

discussion.content: lmfao. Some of these questions..

Selected Answer: D
The placement of a honeypot on the network depends on what your purpose for placing it is. If you want to see attacks coming from the internet into your DMZ, then put it there, but that will miss attackers coming in through a client inside the network (think BEC). In all practicality, they should be placed EVERYWHERE on your network. However, I completely disagree that "it doesn't matter." It certainly DOES MATTER where you place it.

Selected Answer: D
If the honeypot is in front of firewall then logical thinking it's safe but too obvious. The threat actor is not a silly guy :-). So look like D is better answer.

Selected Answer: D
I say D just for the fact of; if I were a threat actor and I see an externally facing resource, I'm going to assume its a honeypot and not interact with it. If it says its a DC or something and inside were files like "important" or "top-secret" its pretty easy to deduce that this isnt worth my time infiltrating most likely and any interaction I have on pulling files would be flagged and I would immediately be identified. My best bet would be to continue enumerating and seeking out POCs for lateral movement. D just makes more sense as you could deploy externally facing honeypots and internal honeypots to catch threats inside the wire

The idea of honey pot is to learn all attack can be launched against a network externally,to get 
accurate result place it in front of a firewall.

As long as the intention is to honeypot some critical servers, D is correct: You will deploy a honeypot in the same datacenter as you have your SQL database. Will deploy too on the same place you have your Apache2 running, and probably you will deploy a honeypot on the same net segment you have an DC running. Cause idea is, to emulate any system you want, really does not matter where to deploy: All is fake

comments.content: It depends on how you plan to use a honeypot. If we want to discover attack types against our network (which why we use honeypot) then C is correct. If we want to use it as a deception system. Then D is correct. But generally all the responses are fake on the honeypot so I may go with D for this question.

discussion.content: C should be the answer..
I support C too but I have seen it some where as D. I was suprised too
Answer shd be C

choices.B: Use a system that is not directly interacting with the router
choices.C: Use it on a system in an external DMZ in front of the firewall
choices.A: Use a system that has a dynamic addressing on the network
choices.D: It doesn't matter as all replies are faked

questions.question_text: Lance wants to place a honeypot on his network. Which of the following would be your recommendations?

What is the CIDR from the following screenshot?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct answer D just /8. It looks like there is a typo in the answer
FYI, (im 99% sure theres no one studying this exam that would need this info) /32 = 255.255.255.255, /24 = 255.255.255.0, /16 = 255.255.0.0, /8 = 255.0.0.0

questions.question_text: What technique is used by JPEGs for compression?

discussion.content: JPEG uses a lossy form of compression based on the discrete cosine transform (DCT).

questions.question_text: What file is processed at the end of a Windows XP boot to initialize the logon dialog box?

discussion.content: LSASS.exe is launched after the winlogon.exe

Selected Answer: C
The question is "What file is processed at the end of a Windows XP boot ?" . Actually the Session Manager Process (SMSS.EXE) triggers Winlogon.exe, which presents the user login screen for user authorization. However the SMSS.EXE is not the option in this question. So LSASS.EXE is the best answer because this file is processed at the end of Windows XP boot process.

The correct answer is A, because the question is asking the file processed BEFORE the logon dialog box appears. Basically, they are asking the required file that is processed before winlogon.exe (the exe that shows the logon dialog box), which is ntoskrnl.exe.

http://etutorials.org/Microsoft+Products/microsoft+windows+xp+professional+training+kit/Chapter+18+-+Modifying+and+Troubleshooting+the+Boot+Process/Lesson+1nbspUnderstanding+the+Boot+Process/
Is there really still questions about Windows XP on version 10?

I think C is the answer
Winlogon.exe uses 3 main pillars.

 SCM: Service Control Manager: in charge of the user-mode services
 LSASS: Local Security Authentication Server: this service handles the authentication requests.
 Userenv.dll:
 Runs the Group Policy Objects
 Loads the User Profile

Logon

The logon process begins at the conclusion of the kernel initialization phase. The Win32 subsystem automatically starts WINLOGON.EXE, which starts the Local Security Authority (LSASS.EXE) and displays the Logon dialog box. You can log on at this time, even though Windows XP Professional might still be initializing network device drivers.
The boot sequence uses the following files: NTLDR, BOOT.INI, BOOTSECT.DOS (optional), NTDETECT.COM, and NTOSKRNL.EXE.
C is the answer
C seems to be the answer.
